results.title: Dog day afternoon
results.creator_credit: Sidney Lumet, Martin Elfand, Martin Bregman and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: On August 22, 1972, a ninety-seven degree day in New York City, an extraordinary robbery took place minutes before closing in a branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank. As the blistering day wore on, details about two incompetent robbers and their victims began to emerge, and in a borough, where the absurd is quite commonplace, these details were to develop into one of the most bizarre news stories of the year. Stars Al Pacino, John Cazale, James Broderick, Charles Durning and Chris Sarandon.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sidney Lumet, Martin Elfand, Martin Bregman and Warner Bros Pictures

results.title: Dodge City
results.creator_credit: Michael Curtiz and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Michael Curtiz (Mildred Pierce, Casablanca, Angels with dirty faces) directed this star vehicle for Errol Flynn with whom he collaborated the year before on “The Adventures of Robin Hood”. In “Dodge City” Flynn plays Wade Hatton, a successful and scrupulous man who, with a loyal crew in tow, herds buffalo across Texas to various destinations. On one such trip the crew are also protecting settler families headed for Dodge City. The frontier life is depicted as dangerous and corrupt, especially in towns thriving on alcohol, gambling and prostitution. As a town with no sheriff, Dodge City is such a town - violent, lawless and ruled by the local saloon owner who murders any individual that tries to collect on honest debts. As a principled and fearless man, Hatton is implored to be sheriff and clean up Dodge City. Flynn is well cast as Hatton, a charming and handsome cowboy. Oliva de Havilland (who starred as Maid Marion in The Adventures of Robin Hood) plays his love interest Abbie Irving, a schoolteacher and journalist. As a Western intended for the Saturday matinee “Dodge City” is replete with scenes of cattle stampedes, bar room brawls and runaway trains. “Dodge City” features some glorious exterior scenes and was filmed in Technicolour.

results.title: Doctor De Soto
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel, Weston Woods Studios and Michael Sporn
results.brief_description: Doctor De Soto, a mouse dentist, refuses to treat animals “dangerous” to mice, until one day a fox shows up writhing in pain from a toothache. How Doctor De Soto and his assistant, Mrs. De Soto “outfox the fox” is a humorous story.

results.title: District Commissioner
results.creator_credit: Maslyn Williams, Shan Benson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
The work of a District Commissioner in the Papua New Guinea highlands. Follows Tom Ellis on patrol: establishing medical posts, providing agricultural advice and equipment, taking a populaiton census and later establishing a patrol post. Shows the importance of air-dropped supplies, until airstrips and roads are laid, and the value of roads to primitive people.

results.title: Dirty Harry
results.creator_credit: Don Siegel, Warner Bros Pictures and Malpaso Company
results.brief_description: Harry Callaghan is a tough, streetwise San Francisco cop whom they call Dirty Harry. In this classic film, you will see why. You will also see why Clint Eastwood’s reputation is secure. No other actor can match his presence. He is magnetising in his portrayal as the shoot-first-ask-questions-later law enforcer who must hunt a psychotic roof-top killer who has slain two people and has kidnapped a girl and threatens to suffocate her if his ransom demands are not met. Harry will get him… one way or the other… no matter what the “system” prescribes. Moody cinematography and stunning location filming propel the story and capitalise upon Eastwood’s commanding presence. Watch this film and ask yourself: Do you feel lucky?

results.title: Dinky Hocker
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America, Robert Guenette, Diane Asselin, Paul Asselin and Tom Blank
results.brief_description: Portrays the plight of a girl who is addicted to food and whose mother is too busy to be concerned. In the face of her mother’s opposition to her attempts at dieting and with the friendship of a young man who shares her addiction, Dinky makes one last attempt to gain her mother’s attention. Based on the book “Dinky Hocker Shoots Smack” by M.E. Kerr.

results.title: Diggers
results.creator_credit: Frank Thring and Efftee Film Productions
results.brief_description: This was the first feature film of the Melbourne enterprise Efftee Films and was adapted for the screen by Pat Hanna from three sketches from his popular Diggers stage show, which featured two Australian cobbers serving in the AIF in France in 1918. The first episode presents the two friends in their attempts to steal rum from a British Army Store; the second episode shows them relaxing in a French cafe while a fellow digger romances with the waitress; the final episode finds the diggers in hospital feigning illness to escape active duty. Cast includes Pat Hanna and George Moon.

results.title: Diary for Timothy
results.creator_credit: Basil Wright, Crown Film Unit and Humphrey Jennings
results.brief_description: Timothy Jenkins was born on 3rd September 1944; this is a diary for him, a diary of the world at war into which he was born, and the transition period from war to peace. For civilians in these stirring times, life went on; a renaissance of interest in the arts was demonstrated by the enthusiasm accorded performances by such artists as John Gielgud and Dame Myra Hess in factory canteens and service hostels. The film ends with a question for Timothy: “What is he going to do when he grows up to make the world a better place for other babies who will be born into it?”. None of the characters or even events in this diary are fictitious- in fact, not a foot of this film was shot in the studios. It is a true record of old, unhappy, but not-so-far-off things made for one who was too young at the time to know what was happening, so that he may review these events when he was older. The commentary was written by E. M. Forster and spoken by Michael Redgrave.

results.title: Dial M for murder
results.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Alfred Hitchcock agreed to direct this masterful adaptation of the Broadway play by Frederick Knott merely to fulfil studio contractual obligations but “Dial M for Murder” became one of his most acclaimed thrillers. Anxious to inherit his wife’s fortune, society playboy Tony Wendice (Ray Milland) ingeniously plots her murder. Blackmailing a former associate with a criminal record, he arranges what appears to be a perfect crime. However, his scheme is foiled when Margot (Grace Kelly) stabs her attacker with scissors. Wendice must now take his sinister web of intrigue in a different direction to cover his tracks. Co-starring John Williams.

results.title: Derek Jarman's Blue
results.creator_credit: Derek Jarman, Takashi Asai, James MacKay and Basilisk Communications, Uplink
results.brief_description: Derek Jarman’s last film, made as he was dying from an AIDS related illness, is a devastating exploration of death and dying. Delivered in Jarman’s own voice-over, with assistance from Nigel Terry, Tilda Swinton and John Quentin, the film is a testimony to courage; it is also a farewell to love, and to life. By turns sad and exhilarating, the shimmering blue of the screen becomes a canvas across which the audience interacts with the essayist filmmaker. Jarman was one of the English-language world’s most daring, transgressive and experimental film artists and it is fitting that his last film continues his maverick’s love for exploration and the avant-garde. Right to the end, his wit and intelligence were undiminished. NOTE: VISUALS CONSIST OF BLUE SCREEN
